entries.title: Bolsonaro Cheered by Florida Supporters Who Say ‘Don’t Go Home’
entries.description: Brazilians following Jair Bolsonaro in Florida, where he’s been on vacation since before his term ended last year, have one message to the former Brazilian president: don’t go home.

entries.title: South Africa Government Faces Legal Threat Over Crippling Blackouts
entries.description: Opposition politicians and South Africa’s biggest labor union say they’re readying a lawsuit against the head of the state-owned power company and a government official that oversees it as blackouts cripple the nation.

entries.title: Japan Pushes Global Counterparts to Regulate Crypto Like Banks
entries.description: Japan is urging the world’s regulators to treat crypto as strictly as they do banks, adding to the calls for tougher rules following the collapse of Sam Bankman-Fried’s FTX digital-asset exchange.

entries.title: California Officials Forecast Dry Weather for Rest of January
entries.description: California will start to see dry weather conditions for the rest of the month, according to state officials, marking a reprieve from a series of damaging storms that rolled off the Pacific for the past several weeks.

entries.title: On King's Holiday, Daughter Calls For Bold Action Over Words
entries.description: Atlanta (AP) -- America has honored Martin Luther King Jr. with a federal holiday for nearly four decades yet still hasn’t fully embraced and acted on the lessons from the slain civil rights leader, his youngest daughter said Monday.

entries.title: Banxico Should Keep Peak Rate for Minimum Six Months, Board Member Says
entries.description: Jonathan Heath sees Mexico’s key rate peaking between 10.75% and 11.5% and remaining in “restrictive territory” for a good part of the year

entries.title: Anti-Inflation Protests Spread Across Venezuela as Wages Dwindle
entries.description: Teachers marched through downtown Caracas on Monday, the latest in a growing number of protests by public sector workers demanding higher wages as they fall behind in an economy that has embraced the US dollar.

entries.title: Baby, Teen Mom Among 6 Killed in Shooting at California Home
entries.description: Visalia, Calif. (AP) -- Six people — including a 17-year-old mother and her 6-month-old baby — were killed in a shooting early Monday at a home in central California, and authorities are searching for at least two suspects, sheriff's officials said.

entries.title: Business Chiefs and Economists Brace for Recession as Davos Begins
entries.description: The World Economic Forum’s annual meeting began in Davos with corporate executives and economists warning a global recession is likely this year.

entries.title: Poll Leader in Nigeria Presidential Election Pledges Debt Revamp
entries.description: Peter Obi, the top choice in four opinion polls ahead of next month’s Nigerian elections, has promised to reprofile the nation’s debt if elected.

entries.title: EU Industry Policy Shakeup Must Include Tax Credits, France Says
entries.description: Bruno Le Maire, France's finance minister, delivers a speech at the Penly nuclear power plant in Penly, France, on Friday, Dec. 9, 2022. France's nuclear reactors are returning to the market just as the cold snap worsens, EDF's Chief Executive Officer Luc Remont said the restart of its units provides confidence that it can make it through a challenging winter.

entries.title: Europe Needs to Debate US Climate Law, Eurogroup Chief Says
entries.description: Europe should discuss new common instruments to counter the impact of the US’s massive clean tech package and boost the bloc´s competitiveness, Eurogroup president Paschal Donohoe said.

entries.title: Hamas Releases Video Purporting to Show Israeli Captive in Gaza
entries.description: Hamas, the militant group that rules Gaza, has released a video for the first time that purports to show an Israeli citizen who’s been held in the coastal strip for years.

entries.title: UK, EU Vow to Keep Pushing for Brexit Deal on Northern Ireland
entries.description: The UK and European Union pledged to continue working toward a post-Brexit deal for Northern Ireland, but stopped short of formally announcing an intense final phase of negotiations.

entries.title: Europe Has Chance to Avoid Deep Recession, EU’s Gentiloni Says
entries.description: Europe has an opportunity to avoid a deep and prolonged recession though the economic situation remains uncertain, the European Union’s economy commissioner, Paolo Gentiloni, said Monday.

entries.title: Chile’s Boric Sees Approval Hit All-Time Low as Troubles Mount
entries.description: Only 25% of Chileans back their president after unpopular pardons, a new poll shows

entries.title: Chelsea Deal for Mudryk to Send $25 Million for Ukraine Defense
entries.description: Ukraine’s armed forces will get $25 million from the country’s richest man for the sale of soccer player Mykhaylo Mudryk to football club Chelsea FC in a deal that underscores the far-reaching consequences of Russia’s invasion.

entries.title: Russia’s Seaborne Crude Flows Surge to Their Highest Since April
entries.description: A jump in Baltic shipments helped crude volumes rise to 3.8 million barrels a day last week

entries.title: South Africa Set to Welcome Russian Warships Despite Criticism
entries.description: South Africa will next month go ahead with naval exercises off its eastern coast with Russian and Chinese warships in a decision that could further strain its relationship with some of its biggest trading partners.

entries.title: Tokyo, Berlin Brace for a More Dangerous World
entries.description: To gauge the titanic shift in how countries are viewing their immediate security challenges look no further than Japan and Germany.

entries.title: Hungary’s New Graft Fighter Says Orban’s System Isn’t Corrupt
entries.description: The head of Hungary’s new agency charged with rooting out everything from shady public contracts to outright fraud said Prime Minister Viktor Orban’s system isn’t corrupt, it’s individuals who are.

entries.title: Yellen Sets Surprise US-Chinese Meeting With Liu in Switzerland
entries.description: US Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen will hold her first face-to-face meeting with Chinese Vice Premier Liu He on Jan. 18 in Zurich, making a detour on her way to talks in Africa.

entries.title: Ukraine Latest: Dnipro Toll Rises; German Defense Chief Resigns
entries.description: The death toll from a missile strike on a nine-story apartment building in the eastern Ukrainian city of Dnipro climbed to 36 as Russian attacks spread to other cities.

entries.title: Control of Turkish Parliament at Stake as Kurd Party Faces Ban
entries.description: Turkey’s biggest pro-Kurdish party said President Recep Tayyip Erdogan and main ally could potentially recapture a majority in the country’s parliament if a court goes ahead with a ban on the group.

entries.title: German Defense Minister Lambrecht Steps Down After Missteps
entries.description: German Defense Minister Christine Lambrecht resigned following a series of missteps and days of speculation over her future, a blow to Chancellor Olaf Scholz’s government as it weighs crucial decisions over arming Ukraine.

entries.title: Japan, India Hold First Joint Air Drill As China Concerns Grow
entries.description: Japan and India held their first joint air drills in an area outside of Tokyo as both countries step up military exercises with other countries amid worries about China’s assertiveness.

entries.title: Italy’s Most-Wanted Mafia Boss Messina Denaro Arrested
entries.description: Fugitive mafia boss Matteo Messina Denaro has been arrested on Monday by Italian military police after thirty years in hiding.

entries.title: Inflation Expectations Climb Before South African Rate Decision
entries.description: South African inflation expectations rose for the next two years, affirming predictions that the central bank will prolong its most aggressive rate-hiking cycle in at least two decades.

entries.title: Poland Eyes Prompt German Approval For Tank Transfer to Ukraine
entries.description: Polish Prime Minister Mateusz Morawiecki signaled on Monday that he expects Germany to give an approval shortly to send Leopard battle tanks to Ukraine.

entries.title: Ramaphosa Ditches Davos as ‘Extreme’ Blackouts Hobble Economy
entries.description: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa canceled his attendance at this year’s World Economic Forum to deal with an escalating energy crisis that’s hobbling the nation’s economy.

entries.title: China’s Hospital Covid Death Data Just a Tenth of Total Toll
entries.description: The nearly 60,000 Covid-related deaths China reported for the first five weeks of its current outbreak, the largest the world has ever seen, may underestimate the true toll by hundreds of thousands of fatalities, experts said.

entries.title: Turkish President Erdogan Keeps the World Guessing on NATO Expansion
entries.description: Six months since Turkey agreed to NATO allies inviting Sweden and Finland to join the alliance, the expansion has stalled as Ankara holds out on ratifying the applications.

entries.title: DPP Picks ‘Worker for Taiwanese Independence’ as New Leader
entries.description: Taiwan’s ruling party has chosen Vice President William Lai as its next chairman, putting the self-described “political worker for Taiwanese independence” in line to be a top challenger in the next presidential election.

entries.title: US Climate Envoy John Kerry Says He Backs UAE Oil Chief Overseeing COP28
entries.description: Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates (AP) -- U.S. climate envoy John Kerry backs the United Arab Emirates' decision to appoint the CEO of a state-run oil company to preside over the upcoming U.N. climate negotiations in Dubai, citing his work on renewable energy projects.

entries.title: Sparks Will Fly in the Electric-Car Trade War
entries.description: A new US law to catch up in EVs raises the stakes for a European response

entries.title: Germany’s Debt Dilemma Tempts Finance Chief Into Bending Rules
entries.description: Germany’s finance minister plans to slam the debt brake back on this year even as he spends billions to cushion the fiscally conservative country from the energy crisis, a challenge that requires some uncharacteristic rule-bending.

entries.title: NYC Mayor Says ‘Cities Are Being Undermined’ by Migrant Crisis
entries.description: New York City Mayor Eric Adams wrapped up a 24-hour trip to El Paso, Texas, on Sunday by demanding that the federal government do more to coordinate services to asylum seekers being bused from the US-Mexico border to the nation’s cities.

entries.title: Australian Employment Outpaced G-7 After Election, Chalmers Says
entries.description: Australian employment growth outpaced every Group of Seven economy in the six months through November, Treasurer Jim Chalmers said, as a survey showed hiring likely remained solid in the final month of last year.

entries.title: Brexit Talks Are Closing In on a Possible Customs Solution
entries.description: UK and European Union negotiators are closing in on a resolution to end their long-running dispute over post-Brexit trading arrangements in Northern Ireland.

entries.title: Sunak Plans to Strengthen Anti-Protest Laws With Police Powers
entries.description: UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak plans to strengthen anti-protest legislation, giving police additional powers to clamp down on demonstrations even before they’ve caused any disruption.

entries.title: Lawmaker Pushes UK to Change Law So Daughters Can Inherit Peerages
entries.description: The "last bastion of constitutional sexism" under which only men can inherit seats in the House of Lords should be abolished, a Conservative former minister has said.

entries.title: UK Teachers May Go On Strike as Sunak Battles to Contain Unrest
entries.description: Teachers may join hundreds of thousands of UK employees taking industrial action as Prime Minister Rishi Sunak’s administration battles to contain a surge of worker unrest over pay that’s failing to keep pace with rampant inflation.

entries.title: Energy, Chips, Taiwan: Flashpoints for 2023 in a Fractured World
entries.description: Business chiefs gathered in Davos are weighing new risks in a global economy where great-power politics loom large and governments are much readier to intervene
